Bleeding oesophageal varices_1:
Patient Description 1:
A 52-year-old male with a history of alcohol abuse presented with a severe episode of hematemesis, rating his pain at 8/10. The bleeding was profuse and persistent, necessitating multiple transfusions. The patient has a known medical history of cirrhosis, and clinical examination revealed signs of portal hypertension. Endoscopy confirmed the presence of bleeding oesophageal varices. The diagnostic process was significantly influenced by the coexistence of portal hypertension and cirrhosis, as well as the refractory nature of the bleeding.
Bleeding oesophageal varices_2:
Patient Description 2:
A 45-year-old female, diagnosed with cirrhosis due to chronic hepatitis C, was admitted with symptoms of hematemesis and melena. The patient described her abdominal pain as 7/10 in intensity. She had experienced multiple episodes of bleeding in the past, which had required medical intervention. On this occasion, the bleeding was attributed to oesophageal varices, as confirmed by endoscopy. The presence of cirrhosis, along with the history of refractory bleeding, significantly influenced the diagnostic process.
Bleeding oesophageal varices_3:
Patient Description 3:
A 58-year-old male, with a long-standing history of alcohol consumption, presented with hematemesis and hematochezia. The patient reported severe upper abdominal pain, which he rated at 9/10. Physical examination indicated stigmata of chronic liver disease, and laboratory tests revealed coagulopathy and thrombocytopenia. Endoscopy identified active bleeding from oesophageal varices. The diagnostic process was notably influenced by the combined presence of portal hypertension, cirrhosis, and the severity of the refractory bleeding episodes.
